it’s really strange because despite the fact that I still don’t necessarily endorse the way our two mcs got together in the end, i’m still okay with it. maybe because it feels like they were meant to end up together anyway given their history and their sexual compatibility. (it’s not like mc mindbroke her. he just made her realize she wasn’t as happy as she could be) i dunno, i’m probably biased towards mc but at least i don’t feel guilty anymore.

[ctd]

to those who say that it just wasn’t fair for seiya because he never saw this coming, my view is that this was only the case as he was complacent. look i did want to give him a chance but after reevaluating his character again i now have the impression that he never cared enough about his girl. it just seems like the sex was all that mattered to him. (tbh that would’ve been fine if he was actually good at it?) furthermore if you think that junpei is just as hungry for sex alone i urge you to read the whole story again and see just how committed he was to making female mc his wife even after all those years.

if there’s any consolation for seiya it’s at least that he didn’t have to physically witness any of the cheating. that would’ve killed him.

[ctd]

this wasn’t the case with seiya. while he did seem to be a decent guy, he never bothered to make sure that his girl felt good too. this is clear right from the start where he turns down her request to go a second time just because he alone had had enough. he did have some resolve to perform better when he caught her masturbating twice but he didn’t really try in the end (passing out after one round wtf?).

i still don’t think that the female mc communicated her feelings to her bf well, and i also don’t condone cheating irl. and while i feel like mc deserved a chance to prove himself, i feel like the whole ntr plan just wasn’t the right way to do it (i dunno, what do you guys think? is it fine to steal a girl from another guy? and this way?).
however despite all this i also feel like seiya could’ve worked a little harder to keep his girl.

initially i really didn’t know what to feel. whose side should i be on? is what i asked myself.

I feel like this doujin touches some points around the importance of caring for your partner. By no means is cheating acceptable, but this doujin and its artist at the very least told you to have a better look at your partner and realizing what they actually need. Now this is some quality in a doujin.

On a broader note, this author's work seem to strongly revolve around paying attention to your partner, but with just as strong base in very Japanese issue of needing to "read the room" aka figuring out what is going on with non-verbal communication, which may seem a bit unfair to western reader. It seems he focuses more on creating cautionary tales with actual real world application, than "she was taken away by big dick against her will and there was nothing you could have done" that you can see more commonly in NTR.
Other stuff is on a completely other side of "wholesome" scale, so don't read it if you are not in for big pill of post-NTR regret.

Dogmatic adherence to social contracts. Saya choose Junpei who loves her from his heart and is willing to constantly show consideration for her feelings and she end up living happier than before. On the other hand, Seiya took his relationship with Saya and his sexual happiness for granted instead of actively trying to satisfy Saya and her needs and he ends up alone and sad. But of course, it is just a story and this isn't true all the time. Nevertheless, the author uses comedy to show us an aspect of relationships that is often missed in most NTR porn. If you read this work and feel a sense of refreshment, don't be surprised. Too many NTR works out there nowadays fetishize the unfaithful wife trope and the sexual predator in position of power trope. If you feel blackpilled after reading too much of those, this work can be a nice reminder to you that real life is more complicated than a 16 pages doujinshi can ever describe to you.

Finally a masterpiece that parodies its own genre. I think it poke fun at the the NTR genre which almost always simply focus on the "taken" (torare) aspect, by having a longer story along with deeper character development showing that relationships in reality is complicated and never cut and dry. In real life relationships, a person never "belongs" to someone else. Instead, what they have are memories they have together along with a touch of social norms and contracts such as promises or relationship definitions. In a story like this, there is no objective answer to the question: "Who is she taken from and where she truly belong". Because things such as promises and relationships are largely based on context and subjective interpretation. And these ties and bonds can sometimes stand between a person and happiness. And by having the childhood friend prevail at the end, I think the author is making a point that love and commitment leads people toward happiness instead of (Continued)
